Basic Salad Mix - Microgreens Seeds Other Name(s): Mixed Variety Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 18 grams Blackout Time: 2-4 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 8-12 days Microgreen Color: mostly green with purple and red highlights Microgreen Flavor: nutty, fresh brassica flavors, mild spice Microgreen Texture: crunchy, fresh Nutrients: Vitamins K, E, and C, calcium, iron, and beta-carotenes Growing Directions: These greens grow well together and have similar germination and harvest times. Radish - Rambo (Organic) - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Raphanus sativus Other Name(s): Presoak: No soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 1-2 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 6-10 days Microgreen Color: spectacular purple Microgreen Flavor: nutty, spicy and fresh Microgreen Texture: crunchy Nutrients: Vitamins A, B, C, E, and K, calcium iron, magnesium, phosphorus, potassium, zinc and essential amino acids Growing Directions: Rambo radish is fast and easy to grow. The microgreen is substantial and very crunchy. Due to its fast growth it can be harvested as early as 6 days, assuming you have exposed it to light on day 3. You can flip the lid a day before exposing to light to strengthen the crop. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Radish microgreens are packed with nutritional benefits! Shell On (Whole), Non-GMO. Open Pollinated. Helianathus Annus. 8-12 Days for mature, delicious microgreens. Black Oil sunflower seeds are some of the best seeds for microgreens beginners. Black Oil sunflower shoots are one of the sweetest and mildest microgreens available, ideal for those new to the wonderfully diverse flavors of microgreens. Microgreens seeds available for Bulk and Custom Fulfillment. ~500 seeds/oz. Black Oil Sunflower Seeds will no longer be sorted by seed size. Read moreHere. More Uses for Sunflower Seeds: Sunflower Sprouts Garden Sunflower Sunflower Scientific Name: Helianthus annuus Microgreen Difficulty: Easy Pre-Soaking Sunflower Seeds: 3-6 hours in cold water Sunflower Microgreens Harvest: 7-10 days Sunflower Microgreens Medium: Soil-based media such as potting soil coconut coir Black Oil Sunflower Color: Even green shoots with some light flavorful yellowing Sunflower Microgreens Flavor: Nutty, sweet, savory, and oily with minimal bitterness Sunflower Microgreens Nutrition: Protein, Calcium, Iron, Potassium, Phosphorus, Magnesium, Vitamin A, C, B-Complex Black Oil Sunflower Microgreen Seeds Sweet, crunchy, and deliciously nutty, conventional Black Oil sunflower microgreens are the new standard for home microgreens. Similar to other larger microgreen seeds, soil-based sunflower sprouts are ready to harvest within 7-10 days at the peak of freshness and flavor. If you're tired of traditional wheatgrass that's only edible when juiced, try Black Oil sunflower microgreen seeds for delicious, savory, and 100% edible sunflower shoots. If intending to sprout for edible 7-10 day microgreens, be sure to only buy sunflower microgreen seeds online that list the seeds as being exclusively sold as \"microgreens seeds\". Flowering ornamentals such as garden sunflower are not typically consumed and their seeds can sometimes be chemically treated to help improve garden performance. Conventional sunflower microgreen seeds are available in small paper packets for microgreens seeds wholesale and available in bulk sizing up to 25 lbs. Growing Black Oil Sunflower Microgreens Seeds Complete Microgreens Growing Instructions Microgreen seeds are a faster and healthier alternative to growing mature fruiting crops while just doing so in only 7-10 days. Most microgreen seeds and sunflower sprouts are ready to harvest at about 3-4\" tall after the shoots have developed true leaves and plenty of falvorful green chlorophyll. If you've never had any experience sprouting microgreen seeds, perhaps try a smaller microgreens batch such as a 5x5 insert until more comfortable to fill out an entire 10x10 or 10x20 microgreens tray. Regardless of size, fill the tray half full with a soil-based or hydroponic medium of your choosing. It's recommended to seed about 9 oz of presoaked Black Oil sunflower seeds over an entire 10x20 sprouting tray prepared with your growing medium. While this is only a recommended seeding rate, simply add one even layer of presoaked seeds to the top of your soil before covering with no more than an inch of soil. Benefits of Black Oil Sunflower Microgreens Although similar in name, Black Seed Oil derived from the Ranunculus family comes from the Nigella sativa plant and is very different from the oils found in Black Oil sunflower seeds. Vitamin E is a fat-soluble antioxidant found in some of the most naturally oily garden crops such as avocado, grape, palm, and nuts. However, because sunflower grows so effortlessly, there is no ethical dilemma to its production and harvest as there is with palm and avocado production. The naturally occurring oil found in Black Oil sunflower seeds from Helianthus annuus is pleasant, mild, and nearly tasteless for fine cooking whereas true Black Seed Oil from Nigella sativa is bitter, pungent, and rarely consumed raw. Sunflower Microgreens Vs Sunflower Sprouts Whether it be the use of raw soil, coco coir, or a hydroponic pad such as jute or bamboo, the growing of microgreen seeds strictly requires the use of some type of medium. The reason for the medium is to help incubate the microgreen seeds for better germination. For some tougher seeds such as Black Oil sunflower, the warmth and microbes help to break down the exterior shell, no different than if growing in the garden. Seed sprouting, as opposed to soil-based microgreen seeds, is 100% hydroponic and does not require any soils or pads to make contact with the seeds. Sprouting seeds germinate simply with a few daily rinses. Before deciding whether to try microgreen seeds or sprouting seeds, understand your seed first to know whether it prefers soil-based growing like sunflower or cilantro, or if it is truly a hydroponic sprouting seed like clover or alfalfa. Next time you're going to the Ball Park, try conventional Black Oil sunflower sprouting and microgreen seeds as a healthy alternative to overly salted sunflower snacks. Black Oil Sunflower Seeds Nutrition The miracle of microgreens allows us to consume some the healthiest fruits and vegetables in the world in only a matter of days from seeding. As consumers, we are able to take advantage of the essential vitamins and minerals available to young seedlings at the time of germination. Harvesting 7-10 day microgreen sunflower sprouts is much easier than harvesting fruits and vegetables while boasting even more vitamins, nutrients, and minerals than fully developed crops. Black Oil sunflower sprouts are rich with protein and amino acids along with essential bone-healthy calcium and trace minerals such as iron, potassium, phosphorus, and magnesium. Aside from shellfish, the only natural sources of trace minerals are in vegetable rich diets and microgreens shoots are proven to be one of the best sources for trace minerals. Sunflower microgreens are intended to be consumed fully green after developing a healthy amount of chlorophyll. The slightly longer 7-10 harvest window allows for microgreen sprouts such as Black Oil sunflower enough time to develop the flavorful green chlorophyll. Tender and delicious 7-10 day microgreen sunflower shoots still produce as much fiber as fully matured fruits and vegetables but are much easier to chew and digest. Most microgreen seeds and sunflower sprouts are ready to harvest at about 3-4\" tall after the shoots have developed true leaves and plenty of falvorful green chlorophyll.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you've never had any experience sprouting microgreen seeds, perhaps try a smaller microgreens batch such as a \u003ca href=\"https://www.trueleafmarket.com/products/5-5-small-growing-tray-inserts?variant=38618483848\" target=\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e5x5\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e insert until more comfortable to fill out an entire \u003ca href=\"https://www.trueleafmarket.com/products/10-10-growing-tray-without-drain-holes?variant=38553846152\" target=\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e10x10\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca href=\"https://www.trueleafmarket.com/products/10-20-growing-trays-without-holes?variant=38551591816\" target=\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e10x20\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e microgreens tray.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRegardless of size, fill the tray half full with a soil-based or hydroponic medium of your choosing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt's recommended to seed about 9 oz of presoaked Black Oil sunflower seeds over an entire 10x20 sprouting tray prepared with your growing medium.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile this is only a recommended seeding rate, simply add one even layer of presoaked seeds to the top of your soil before covering with no more than an inch of soil.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/VGVz9Oszp24?si=v-0RGTu0O9aJSF7a\" title=\"YouTube video player\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\" allowfullscreen=\"\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"padding-bottom: 5px;\"\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBenefits of Black Oil Sunflower Microgreens\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"padding-bottom: 5px;\"\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough similar in name, Black Seed Oil derived from the Ranunculus family comes from the Nigella sativa plant and is very different from the oils found in Black Oil sunflower seeds.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVitamin E is a fat-soluble antioxidant found in some of the most naturally oily garden crops such as avocado, grape, palm, and nuts. However, because sunflower grows so effortlessly, there is no ethical dilemma to its production and harvest as there is with palm and avocado production.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe naturally occurring oil found in Black Oil sunflower seeds from \u003cem\u003eHelianthus annuus\u003c/em\u003e is pleasant, mild, and nearly tasteless for fine cooking whereas true Black Seed Oil from Nigella sativa is bitter, pungent, and rarely consumed raw.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"col-lg-4 col-xs-12 wgk-brand fp-cat-block\"\u003e\u003cimg class=\"pic-align img-fluid w100 lazyload\" src=\"https://cdn.shopify.com/s/files/1/2016/2681/files/OGSF_Shoots.jpg?v=1633286739\" alt=\"Black Oil Sunflower Microgreens\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSunflower Microgreens Vs Sunflower Sprouts\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"intl-shipping row\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"col-lg-7 col-xs-12\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"padding-bottom: 5px;\"\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhether it be the use of raw soil, coco coir, or a hydroponic pad such as jute or bamboo, the growing of microgreen seeds strictly requires the use of some type of medium.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe reason for the medium is to help incubate the microgreen seeds for better germination. For some tougher seeds such as Black Oil sunflower, the warmth and microbes help to break down the exterior shell, no different than if growing in the garden.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeed sprouting, as opposed to soil-based microgreen seeds, is 100% hydroponic and does not require any soils or pads to make contact with the seeds. Sprouting seeds germinate simply with a few daily rinses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore deciding whether to try microgreen seeds or sprouting seeds, understand your seed first to know whether it prefers soil-based growing like sunflower or cilantro, or if it is truly a hydroponic sprouting seed like clover or alfalfa.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNext time you're going to the Ball Park, try conventional Black Oil sunflower sprouting and microgreen seeds as a healthy alternative to overly salted sunflower snacks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"col-lg-4 col-xs-12 wgk-brand fp-cat-block\"\u003e\u003cimg class=\"pic-align img-fluid w100 lazyload\" src=\"https://cdn.shopify.com/s/files/1/2016/2681/files/self-watering-trays-sunflower-wm_525d8aa1-0596-46aa-8d46-3ec688894637.jpg?v=1633287156\" alt=\"Black Oil Sunflower Microgreens in Self Watering Tray\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBlack Oil Sunflower Seeds Nutrition\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"padding-bottom: 5px;\"\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe miracle of microgreens allows us to consume some the healthiest fruits and vegetables in the world in only a matter of days from seeding. As consumers, we are able to take advantage of the essential vitamins and minerals available to young seedlings at the time of germination.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHarvesting 7-10 day microgreen sunflower sprouts is much easier than harvesting fruits and vegetables while boasting even more vitamins, nutrients, and minerals than fully developed crops.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBlack Oil sunflower sprouts are rich with protein and amino acids along with essential bone-healthy calcium and trace minerals such as iron, potassium, phosphorus, and magnesium. Aside from shellfish, the only natural sources of trace minerals are in vegetable rich diets and microgreens shoots are proven to be one of the best sources for trace minerals.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSunflower microgreens are intended to be consumed fully green after developing a healthy amount of chlorophyll. The slightly longer 7-10 harvest window allows for microgreen sprouts such as Black Oil sunflower enough time to develop the flavorful green chlorophyll.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTender and delicious 7-10 day microgreen sunflower shoots still produce as much fiber as fully matured fruits and vegetables but are much easier to chew and digest.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eBlack Oil Sunflower Seeds Per Package:\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e5 g - Wholesale - Approximately 88 Seeds\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e4 oz - Wholesale - Approximately 2,000 Slow Bolt Arugula is easy to grow and grows fast as a microgreen. It's a favorite and generally considered a staple of the spicier side of microgreens and baby salad greens. The peppery taste gets less intense as it grows bigger. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Herb Arugula - Slow Bolt - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Eruca Sativa Other Name(s): Roquette, salad rocket, garden rocket Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 9 grams Blackout Time: 1-2 days Germination Time: 1-2 days Estimated time to Harvest: 6-8 days Microgreen Color: green Microgreen Flavor: peppery flavor, slightly buttery and cabbage-like Microgreen Texture: crisp, fresh Nutrients: Vitamins A and C, calcium, iron, and phosphorus Growing Directions: Moisten soil, tamp, and spread the arugula seeds evenly over the growth surface. Cover for 1-2 days. Uncover and place under direct light, or place in an area with sufficient indirect light. Just be sure to rotate your microgreens crop to prevent your greens from bending toward the light and becoming leggy. Harvest when the look and the flavor is to your liking. So, begin sampling the greens when the first set of leaves form to determine when to cut! For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Arugula microgreens are wonderful for helping keep bones healthy and strong. The same amount of calcium is contained in arugula microgreens as is found in spinach. A benefit of the arugula microgreens is that it has a much lower amount of oxalates compared to spinach, which prevent full calcium absorption. Cover for 1-2 days. Uncover and place under direct light, or place in an area with sufficient indirect light. Just be sure to rotate your microgreens crop to prevent your greens from bending toward the light and becoming leggy. Harvest when the look and the flavor is to your liking. So, begin sampling the greens when the first set of leaves form to determine when to cut!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFor more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://trueleafmarket.reamaze.com/articles/growing-microgreens-in-soil\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSoil Growing Directions page\u003c/a\u003e or our\u003cspan\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://trueleafmarket.reamaze.com/articles/how-to-grow-microgreens-hydroponically\" title=\"Microgreens Hydroponic Growing Directions\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eHydroponic Growing Directions page\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFacts:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eArugula microgreens\u003cspan\u003e are wonderful for helping keep bones healthy and strong\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Garden Cabbage - Red Acre - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Brassica oleracea Other Name(s): Pak Choi, Bok Choy Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 2-4 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 6-14 days Microgreen Color: green leaves with violet to red highlights throughout Microgreen Flavor: strong broccoli/cabbage (brassica) flavor Microgreen Texture: soft and fresh Nutrients: Vitamins C, A, and E, beta-carotenes, potassium and iron Growing Directions: Red Acre Cabbage is easy to grow and grows quickly! It grows well in soil or on hydroponic mediums. If using soil, tamp and moisten soil before spreading your microgreen seeds across its surface. You may want to cover seeds with a thin layer of soil. This will keep the seeds moist for longer. Allowing the seeds to germinate on the surface is fine too! Keep dark with the black out dome for the first 3 days then flip the lid on day 4 and 5 to stress and strengthen the crop. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: A 2016 study by the American Chemical Society implies that red cabbage may help reduce \"bad\" cholesterol. It has a consistent flavor compared to other kale microgreens: nutty and robust'similiar to mustard, only less spicy! Select a Different Use for This Seed: Garden Kale - Red Russian - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Brassica oleracea Other Name(s): Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 1-2 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 8-12 days Microgreen Color: assorted red and pink stems with dark green leaves Microgreen Flavor: strong broccoli (brassica) flavor, nutty and rich Microgreen Texture: crunchy, fresh Nutrients: Vitamins A, C, and K, antioxidants, fiber, iron, and copper Growing Directions: Growing kale microgreens is quite easy. As long as you follow a few basic steps, you should have a plentiful harvest of microgreens in no time. Prepare your growth medium, whether it be soil or a hydroponic growth mat, by getting it sufficiently moist. Spread seeds evenly across the surface of the growth medium. The denser you sow the seeds, the thicker your crop will turn out. However, be wary of over-seeding, which can lead to to the seeds becoming overcrowded, leading to crop failure. After seeds are sown, cover for one to two days to allow seeds to germinate, and then uncover seeds and place under a grow light or in a place in your home that gets a lot of sunshine (rotate crop if next to a window to prevent \"bending\" in the microgreens). Continue to water when needed for up to a week and half. By then, you should have a bounty of little greens to incorporate into your meals. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Kale is an extremely nutrient dense food source. With microgreens you can receive all of the health benefits of kale and avoid the sometimes bitter taste that comes with full grown kale. Some of the health benefits of this amazing vegetable include: Full of antioxidants that reduce free radicals, which aids in cancer prevention Anti-inflammatory, which reduces swelling and pain in the body Fortifies immune system and improves brain health Seeds per Package: 1 oz - Approximately 8,000 seeds 4 oz - Approximately 32,000 seeds 1 lb - Approximately 128,000 seeds 5 lb - Approximately 640,000 seeds 25 lb - Approximately 3,200,000 seeds","descriptionHtml":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e8-12 days.\u003c/strong\u003e Check out this vibrant kale microgreen with dark green leaves and variegated stems of pink, floral purple, and at times, bright red. Red Garnet Amaranth is a high-protein microgreen with stunning red and magenta tones. This heirloom variety can be used in salads or many oriental dishes. Amaranth - Red Garnet - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Amaranthus tricolour Other Name(s): Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 2-4 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 8-12 days Microgreen Color: the most vibrant red and pink of any microgreen! Microgreen Flavor: mild, sweet flavor Microgreen Texture: crisp, fresh Nutrients: Vitamins K, E, and C, protein, calcium, iron, and beta-carotenes Growing Directions: Red Garnet Amaranth is a very small, delicate microgreen that prefers warmer growing conditions. Find a nice warm spot for germination and growing. It can also be sensitive to too much direct light. Red Garnet Amaranth does not grow tall, so expect very small greens that will need to be harvested close to the root line and rinsed well. These microgreens seeds do well grown hydroponically or in soil, but soil is a little more forgiving. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Red Garnet Amaranth contains a robust flavor, similar to mustard - but much less spicy. It can add depth to any dish that requires fresh greens--or in this case, reds! It's striking colors make it a great garnish or a lovely addition to any microgreen salad. Dun Pea micro greens are one our all-time favorite microgreens! The pea shoots are sweet and delicious and fairly straight and leafy. They make a great garnish or addition to any salad. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Cover Crop Sprouting Pea - Dun - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Pisum sativum Other Name(s): Pea shoots Presoak: 4-6 hours in cold water (more details below) Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: Amount of seeds may vary. We recommend 5-8 oz Blackout Time: 3-5 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 8-14 days Pea Tendrils Amount: low Microgreen Color: green Microgreen Flavor: sweet, fresh pea taste Microgreen Texture: crunchy succulent Nutrients: Vitamins A, C, E, B1, B2, B3, B6, protein, fiber, omega-3 and micronutrients Growing Directions: Pea microgreens (also known as pea shoots) usually have very prominent root systems, which is why it is primarily grown in soil. The roots like to burrow and explore the soil while taking hold so the shoots can start \"shooting\" up. It is possible to get them to thrive with the right hydroponic medium. Soak seeds in cold water for 4-6 hours. Make sure you use plenty of water and a large bowl, as the peas soak up large amounts of water. You can plant directly, but we prefer to transfer to a colander. Rinse and drain 2-4 times per day in the colander for another day or two until the seedlings begin to peek out. Tamp the soil gently to flatten. Spread evenly (they should be quite thick) and tamp very gently to insure contact with the soil. Mist thoroughly twice a day. Keep covered with the blackout/humidity dome for 2-3 more days before exposing to light. Water once a day so the soil is damp, but not soggy. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Dun pea microgreens are an excellent source of these three protective agents: folate, antioxidants and carotene. Folate aids in the production and maintenance of cells, as well as protects against DNA damage Antioxidants fight against free radical damage, which lowers the risk of cancer Carotenes are helpful antioxidants that specifically protect the body from disease and strengthen the immune system Seeds per Package: 1 lb - Approximately 2,300 seeds 5 lb - Approximately 11,500 seeds 25 lb - Approximately 57,600 seeds","descriptionHtml":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e8-14 days\u003c/strong\u003e. Radish microgreens are substantial and crunchy, and taste exactly like a radish. Very easy and fast growers. Makes a great garnish or addition to any salad or sandwich. Use sparingly for a radish accent. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Sprouting Radish - Daikon (Organic) - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Raphanus sativus var. Longipinnatus Other Name(s): Presoak: No soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 2 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 6-10 days Microgreen Color: creamy white stem with a vibrant green top Microgreen Flavor: fresh and spicy Microgreen Texture: crunchy, succulent Nutrients: Vitamins A, B, C, E, \u0026 K, folic acid, niacin, potassium, iron, phosphorus, pantothenic acid, calcium, magnesium, zinc, carotenes Growing Directions: Radish microgreens are fast and easy to grow and are substantial and very crunchy. Due to its fast growth, it can be harvested as early as 6 days, assuming you have exposed them to light on day 3. These radish microgreens are at their peak of crunchiness at about day 5 or 6. Once they grow larger they get more leafy and lose their crunch. You can flip the lid a day before exposing to light to strengthen the crop. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Daikon Radish is a green crop with an intense radish flavor great in any microgreen salad or full sized salad. Daikon is one of the most popular radishes to sprout as well. Use instead of sliced radish anywhere you would normally use radish. Radish greens have a pleasant peppery bite, whether raw or cooked. A hearty salad made with these greens offers enough nourishment to reduce the need for snacking. This obviously cuts your caloric intake, which stabilizes your daily regimen. Due to its fast growth, it can be harvested as early as 6 days, assuming you have exposed them to light on day 3. These radish microgreens are at their peak of crunchiness at about day 5 or 6. Once they grow larger they get more leafy and lose their crunch. You can flip the lid a day before exposing to light to strengthen the crop.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFor more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://trueleafmarket.reamaze.com/articles/growing-microgreens-in-soil\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSoil Growing Directions page\u003c/a\u003e or our\u003cspan\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://trueleafmarket.reamaze.com/articles/how-to-grow-microgreens-hydroponically\" title=\"Microgreens Hydroponic Growing Directions\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eHydroponic Growing Directions page\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFacts:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDaikon Radish is a green crop with an intense radish flavor great in any microgreen salad or full sized salad. Daikon is one of the most popular radishes to sprout as well. Use instead of sliced radish anywhere you would normally use radish. Radish greens have a pleasant peppery bite, whether raw or cooked. A hearty salad made with these greens offers enough nourishment to reduce the need for snacking. This obviously cuts your caloric intake, which stabilizes your daily regimen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSeeds per Package:\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e4 oz - Approximately 14,000 Select a Different Use for This Seed: Garden Beet - Detroit Dark Red (Conventional) - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Beta vulgaris Other Name(s): Detroit Dark Red Presoak: 4-8 hours in cold water Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: up to 5 days Germination Time: 3-4 days Estimated time to Harvest: 11-21 days Microgreen Color: vibrant red stem with a nearly neon green top Microgreen Flavor: sweet and earthy Microgreen Texture: crunchy, juicy Nutrients: Vitamins A, B, C, E, and K, calcium, magnesium, potassium, iron, zinc, and protein Growing Directions: Grow beet microgreens seeds only in soil. Beet seeds are an abnormally shaped seed, which contributes to why its preferred medium is soil. Their root systems also require a bit more room to explore and grab hold.Prepare your soil in your tray by tamping it and making sure it is moist. After presoaking, sow your seeds and then cover with a thin layer of soil. This provides the ideal conditions for the seeds to germinate. After a while, the beets will start to poke through the the top layer\"which also serves to de-shell the seed. Keep covered with the blackout dome for up to five days. After that, place under a grow light or in sunlight until mature! Cut close to the soil line to feature the red stem. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page. Facts: Beets have so many healthy qualities! There are so many benefits to these tiny, yet powerful plants. Green Pea microgreens are a staff favorite here at True Leaf! The tendrils add a unique texture while the stems have the same familiar crunch and sweet flavor of full grown peas. Green pea is a non-varietal species, and while Organic, can change in characteristics from harvest to harvest (including the amount of tendrils). The photo to the left is of a harvest of green peas with no tendrils. Often this variety has tendrils.~143 seeds/oz. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Sprouting Pea - Green (Organic) - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Pisum sativum Other Name(s): Pea shoots Presoak: 4-6 hours in cold water (more details below) Preferred Growing Medium: Soil (preferred) or Hydroponic (more difficult) Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: Amount of seeds may vary. We recommend 5-8 oz Blackout Time: 3-5 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 8-14 days Pea Tendrils Amount: low to high (depending on the harvest) Microgreen Color: green Microgreen Flavor: sweet, fresh pea taste Microgreen Texture: crunchy, succulent Nutrients: Vitamins A, C, E, B1, B2, B3, B6, protein, fiber, omega-3 and micronutrients Growing Directions: Pea microgreens (also known as pea shoots) usually have very prominent root systems, which is why it is primarily grown in soil. The roots like to burrow and explore the soil while taking hold so the shoots can start \"shooting\" up. It is possible to get them to thrive with the right hydroponic medium. Soak seeds in cold water for 4-6 hours. Make sure you use plenty of water and a large bowl, as the peas soak up large amounts of water. You can plant directly, but we prefer to transfer to a colander. Rinse and drain 2-4 times per day in the colander for another day or two until the seedlings begin to peek out. Tamp the soil gently to flatten. Spread evenly (they should be quite thick) and tamp very gently to insure contact with the soil. Mist thoroughly twice a day. Keep covered with the blackout/humidity dome for 2-3 more days before exposing to light. Water once a day so the soil is damp, but not soggy. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Pea microgreens can aid in diabetes, cancer prevention and overall heart health. They are high in antioxidants and phytonutrients, which are necessary in supporting the body's inflammation system. This slow-bolting strain is grown primarily for its broad, deep green, celery-like, pungent foliage. As a microgreen, these seeds take time but are well worth it, not only for the strong cilantro flavor but for the sweet aroma the greens emit. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Herb Cilantro - Slow Bolt - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Coriandrum sativum Other Name(s): Coriander, dhania Presoak: 4-8 hours in cold water Preferred Growing Medium: Soil (difficult to grow hydroponically) Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 6-7 days Germination Time: 7-10 days Estimated time to Harvest: 21-28 days Microgreen Color: green Microgreen Flavor: full cilantro flavor Microgreen Texture: crisp, fresh Nutrients: Vitamins A, C, E, K, calcium, iron, potassium, dietary fiber and magnesium Growing Directions: Cilantro (also called coriander) is very difficult to grow hydroponically. We recommend growing micro cilantro in soil. Germination of cilantro microgreens is erratic with some emerging at about a week, and some seeds taking longer, so be patient with them. The seed itself is actually the dried ripe fruit of the plant, called a shizocarp. A schizocarp is a dry fruit that splits into single-seeded parts when ripe. Splitting or cracking can help with germination by releasing the seed. Here's how: Place seed in a zip-lock bag and roll over it with a rolling pin to release the individual seeds, rinse in a fine mesh strainer and soak overnight for even germination. Sow quite thickly on a bed of lightly compacted soil. Cover with a thin layer of soil or vermiculite (1/4 inch) and tamp very lightly. Cover in a humidity dome and mist as needed to keep the top layer medium damp. Cilantro micro greens grow slowly and prefer cooler temperatures (under 70 degrees), especially during germination. Experiment with placing your germinating trays in much cooler areas. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page Facts: Some of the amazing health benefits of cilantro are: Eliminates heavy metals from the body Powerful antioxidant that reduces free radicals, which aids in cancer prevention Reduces anxiety and improves sleep Seeds per Package: 1 oz - Approximately 2,000 seeds 4 oz - Approximately 8,000 seeds 1 lb - Approximately 32,000 seeds 5 lb - Approximately 160,000 seeds 25 lb - Approximately 800,000 seeds","descriptionHtml":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e21-28 days.\u003c/strong\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThis slow-bolting strain is grown primarily for its broad, deep green, celery-like, pungent foliage. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Herb Basil - Genovese - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Ocimum basilcum Other Name(s): Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 4-7 days Germination Time: 5-7 days Estimated time to Harvest: 12-16 days Microgreen Color: green Microgreen Flavor: intense basil Microgreen Texture: soft Nutrients: Vitamins E, A, K, B6, and C, protein, calcium, iron, zinc, magnesium, copper, phosphorous, and potassium Growing Directions: Genovese Basil is a mucilaginous seed, meaning that it develops a jelly-like coating when it gets wet. Mist more frequently to keep the coating moist. Grows very well hydroponically and does better in well-lit conditions, but it is a slower grower. You may experiment with harvest times past 10 days. Genovese basil is a beautiful green color with an interesting shape that makes for a colorful garnish. Micro basil does not grow tall, so you will need to harvest close to the root line and rinse well. Micro basil seeds are among the more expensive seeds, but are worth it for their intense basil flavor. ***Note: Although we have indicated the specific medium that this particular seed prefers, you can still experiment with either Hydroponic or Soil mediums. Results may vary. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: As can be seen from the nutrition information above - basil contains so many different nutritional benefits! It's not just a great tasting addition to your cooking. Radish - Rambo (Conventional) - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Raphanus sativus Other Name(s): Presoak: No soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 1-2 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 6-10 days Microgreen Color: spectacular purple Microgreen Flavor: nutty, spicy and fresh Microgreen Texture: crunchy Nutrients: Vitamins A, B, C, E, and K, calcium iron, magnesium, phosphorus, potassium, zinc and essential amino acids Growing Directions: Rambo radish is fast and easy to grow. The microgreen is substantial and very crunchy. Due to its fast growth it can be harvested as early as 6 days, assuming you have exposed it to light on day 3. You can flip the lid a day before exposing to light to strengthen the crop. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Radish microgreens are packed with nutritional benefits! Select a Different Use for This Seed: Garden Sprouting Radish - China Rose (Conventional) - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Raphanus sativus Other Name(s): Presoak: 4-6 hours in cold water Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 2 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 6-10 days Microgreen Color: vibrant pink stem with a deep green top Microgreen Flavor: spicy \u0026 floral with a hint of sweetness Microgreen Texture: crunchy, succulent Nutrients: Vitamins A, B, C, E, \u0026 K, folic acid, niacin, potassium, iron, phosphorus, pantothenic acid, calcium, magnesium, zinc, carotenes Growing Directions: Radish is fast and easy to grow. The microgreen is substantial and very crunchy. Due to its fast growth it can be harvested as early as 6 days, assuming you have exposed it to light on day 3. These radish microgreens are at their peak of crunchiness at about day 5 or 6. Once they grow larger they get more leafy and lose their crunch. You can flip the lid a day before exposing to light to strengthen the crop. ***Note: Although we have indicated the specific medium that this particular seed prefers, you can still experiment with either Hydroponic or Soil mediums. Results may vary. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Garden Swiss Chard - Ruby Red - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Beta vulgaris Other Name(s): Silverbeet, Perpetual Spinach, Spinach beet Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium:Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 4-7 days Germination Time: 2-5 days Estimated time to Harvest: 8-12 days Microgreen Color: deep dark red, hauntingly beautiful Microgreen Flavor: sweet, earthy Microgreen Texture: soft Nutrients: Vitamins A, B, C, E, and K, calcium, magnesium, potassium, iron, zinc, and protein Growing Directions: Grow only in soil. Chard is part of the beet family and the greens look very similar to beet greens.. Cut close to the soil to feature the colorful stem, and rinse well. Beets seeds are abnormally shaped seed, which contributes to why its preferred medium is soil. Their root systems require a bit more room to explore and grab hold. Beet greens are very colorful and flavorful. Prepare your soil in your tray by tamping it and making sure it is moist. after presoak, sow your seeds and then cover with a thin layer of soil. This provides the ideal conditions for the seeds to germinate. After a while, the beets will start to poke through the the top layer\"which also serves to de-shell the seed. Keep covered with the blackout dome for up to five days. After that, place under a growlight until mature! Cut close to the soil line to feature the red stem. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page Facts: Swiss chard is well known for its remarkable nutritional qualities. All of the health benefits of full grown swiss chard are found in microgreen form! A few of these qualities and benefits include: High levels of antioxidants, which can lower the risk of chronic diseases, including cancer Helps prevent high blood pressure and diabetes Boosts digestion Seeds per Package: 1 oz - Approximately 930 seeds 4 oz - Approximately 3,720 seeds 1 lb - Approximately 14,880 seeds 5 lb - Approximately 74,400 seeds 25 lb - Approximately 372,000 seeds","descriptionHtml":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e11-21 days.\u003c/strong\u003e A mild delicate spinach flavor and amazing red stem color. Brassica oleracea var gongylodes. Purple Vienna Kohlrabi Microgreen Seeds. Try adding these as the base of a microgreen salad. Their mild cabbage flavor, paired with colorful stems, creates a delicious and beautiful combination that is perfect for elevating your favorite meals. Try growing on soil or hydroponic growing mediums. ~10,500 seeds/oz. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Garden Growing Microgreens Starter Guide Latin Name: Brassica oleracea var. gongylodes Other Name(s): Presoak: 0 Hours Preferred Growing Medium: Soil or Hydroponic Seeding Rate per 10 inches x 20 inches tray: 0.5 oz Blackout Time: 2-3 days Germination Time: 3-5 days Estimated time to Harvest: 8-12 days Purple Vienna Kohlrabi Microgreen Color: Dark green leaves with rose-colored purple stems Purple Vienna Kohlrabi Microgreen Flavor: Mild cabbage-like Nutrients: 100% daily value of Vitamin C. Also contain Vitamins B1, B6, B9, potassium, phosphorus, and calcium. Kohlrabi - Purple Vienna - Microgreens Seeds Growing Purple Vienna Kohlrabi Microgreen Seeds Because kohlrabi seeds easily germinate, presoaking is not necessary. Try growing on a soil-based or hydroponic growing medium. We always recommend beginners start with soil-based growing media as it is the most forgiving to potential variables. A seeding rate of 0.5 oz for a 10x20 tray is recommended. For easy watering, nestle a tray with holes inside one without. Simply add water in the bottom tray to avoid disrupting your seeds and the new growth throughout the process. Cover your newly planted seeds for the first 2-3 days. Keep your seeds moist but not drowning in water. This will help you avoid molding problems. If mold starts to appear, spray it with a mixture of hydrogen peroxide and water. Kohlrabi microgreens are ready in only 8-12 days. Harvest with a sharp knife or scissors. Benefits of Purple Vienna Kohlrabi Microgreens Kohlrabi has a whole host of benefits, including 100 percent of your daily value of vitamin C. in addition to its nutritional components found in the attributes tab above, kohlrabi’s mild cabbage-like flavor makes it a great pair with other microgreens. Mix and match to create your ideal blend of flavors and texture. Culinary Tips Kohlrabi microgreens are best added to salads, sandwiches, slaw, or as a simple garnish. Of course, don’t let this list stop you from experimenting and trying them out on your favorite foods. Tips From Our Gardeners \"I love microgreens because they can be added to so many different kinds of food. My favorite way to use them is in my breakfast smoothies. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Garden Leek - American Flag - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Allium ampeloprasum Other Name(s): Scotch Flag, Giant Musselburh Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 4-6 days Germination Time: 3-4 days Estimated time to Harvest: 10-12 days Microgreen Color: green Microgreen Flavor: onion Microgreen Texture: stringy Nutrients: Vitamins A and C, calcium, iron, and phosphorus Growing Directions: American Flag Leek seeds will produce best if planted more thickly on your growth medium. A small crop goes a long way, as the onion flavor can overpower a dish if used too heavily. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: The pleasant mild onion flavor is a great compliment to any micro greens salad, and the shape is a contrast to most other microgreens. Excellent substitute for onions anywhere. Fantastic on hamburgers, soups, as garnishes, and more. Radish - Rambo (Organic) - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Raphanus sativus Other Name(s): Presoak: No soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 1-2 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 6-10 days Microgreen Color: spectacular purple Microgreen Flavor: nutty, spicy and fresh Microgreen Texture: crunchy Nutrients: Vitamins A, B, C, E, and K, calcium iron, magnesium, phosphorus, potassium, zinc and essential amino acids Growing Directions: Rambo radish is fast and easy to grow. The microgreen is substantial and very crunchy. Due to its fast growth it can be harvested as early as 6 days, assuming you have exposed it to light on day 3. You can flip the lid a day before exposing to light to strengthen the crop. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Radish microgreens are packed with nutritional benefits! Shell On (Whole), Non-GMO. Open Pollinated. Helianathus Annus. 8-12 Days for mature, delicious microgreens. Black Oil sunflower seeds are some of the best seeds for microgreens beginners. Black Oil sunflower shoots are one of the sweetest and mildest microgreens available, ideal for those new to the wonderfully diverse flavors of microgreens. Microgreens seeds available for Bulk and Custom Fulfillment. ~500 seeds/oz. Black Oil Sunflower Seeds will no longer be sorted by seed size. Read moreHere. More Uses for Sunflower Seeds: Sunflower Sprouts Garden Sunflower Sunflower Scientific Name: Helianthus annuus Microgreen Difficulty: Easy Pre-Soaking Sunflower Seeds: 3-6 hours in cold water Sunflower Microgreens Harvest: 7-10 days Sunflower Microgreens Medium: Soil-based media such as potting soil coconut coir Black Oil Sunflower Color: Even green shoots with some light flavorful yellowing Sunflower Microgreens Flavor: Nutty, sweet, savory, and oily with minimal bitterness Sunflower Microgreens Nutrition: Protein, Calcium, Iron, Potassium, Phosphorus, Magnesium, Vitamin A, C, B-Complex Black Oil Sunflower Microgreen Seeds Sweet, crunchy, and deliciously nutty, conventional Black Oil sunflower microgreens are the new standard for home microgreens. Similar to other larger microgreen seeds, soil-based sunflower sprouts are ready to harvest within 7-10 days at the peak of freshness and flavor. If you're tired of traditional wheatgrass that's only edible when juiced, try Black Oil sunflower microgreen seeds for delicious, savory, and 100% edible sunflower shoots. If intending to sprout for edible 7-10 day microgreens, be sure to only buy sunflower microgreen seeds online that list the seeds as being exclusively sold as \"microgreens seeds\". Flowering ornamentals such as garden sunflower are not typically consumed and their seeds can sometimes be chemically treated to help improve garden performance. Conventional sunflower microgreen seeds are available in small paper packets for microgreens seeds wholesale and available in bulk sizing up to 25 lbs. Growing Black Oil Sunflower Microgreens Seeds Complete Microgreens Growing Instructions Microgreen seeds are a faster and healthier alternative to growing mature fruiting crops while just doing so in only 7-10 days. Most microgreen seeds and sunflower sprouts are ready to harvest at about 3-4\" tall after the shoots have developed true leaves and plenty of falvorful green chlorophyll. If you've never had any experience sprouting microgreen seeds, perhaps try a smaller microgreens batch such as a 5x5 insert until more comfortable to fill out an entire 10x10 or 10x20 microgreens tray. Regardless of size, fill the tray half full with a soil-based or hydroponic medium of your choosing. It's recommended to seed about 9 oz of presoaked Black Oil sunflower seeds over an entire 10x20 sprouting tray prepared with your growing medium. While this is only a recommended seeding rate, simply add one even layer of presoaked seeds to the top of your soil before covering with no more than an inch of soil. Benefits of Black Oil Sunflower Microgreens Although similar in name, Black Seed Oil derived from the Ranunculus family comes from the Nigella sativa plant and is very different from the oils found in Black Oil sunflower seeds. Vitamin E is a fat-soluble antioxidant found in some of the most naturally oily garden crops such as avocado, grape, palm, and nuts. However, because sunflower grows so effortlessly, there is no ethical dilemma to its production and harvest as there is with palm and avocado production. The naturally occurring oil found in Black Oil sunflower seeds from Helianthus annuus is pleasant, mild, and nearly tasteless for fine cooking whereas true Black Seed Oil from Nigella sativa is bitter, pungent, and rarely consumed raw. Sunflower Microgreens Vs Sunflower Sprouts Whether it be the use of raw soil, coco coir, or a hydroponic pad such as jute or bamboo, the growing of microgreen seeds strictly requires the use of some type of medium. The reason for the medium is to help incubate the microgreen seeds for better germination. For some tougher seeds such as Black Oil sunflower, the warmth and microbes help to break down the exterior shell, no different than if growing in the garden. Seed sprouting, as opposed to soil-based microgreen seeds, is 100% hydroponic and does not require any soils or pads to make contact with the seeds. Sprouting seeds germinate simply with a few daily rinses. Before deciding whether to try microgreen seeds or sprouting seeds, understand your seed first to know whether it prefers soil-based growing like sunflower or cilantro, or if it is truly a hydroponic sprouting seed like clover or alfalfa. Next time you're going to the Ball Park, try conventional Black Oil sunflower sprouting and microgreen seeds as a healthy alternative to overly salted sunflower snacks. Black Oil Sunflower Seeds Nutrition The miracle of microgreens allows us to consume some the healthiest fruits and vegetables in the world in only a matter of days from seeding. As consumers, we are able to take advantage of the essential vitamins and minerals available to young seedlings at the time of germination. Harvesting 7-10 day microgreen sunflower sprouts is much easier than harvesting fruits and vegetables while boasting even more vitamins, nutrients, and minerals than fully developed crops. Black Oil sunflower sprouts are rich with protein and amino acids along with essential bone-healthy calcium and trace minerals such as iron, potassium, phosphorus, and magnesium. Aside from shellfish, the only natural sources of trace minerals are in vegetable rich diets and microgreens shoots are proven to be one of the best sources for trace minerals. Sunflower microgreens are intended to be consumed fully green after developing a healthy amount of chlorophyll. The slightly longer 7-10 harvest window allows for microgreen sprouts such as Black Oil sunflower enough time to develop the flavorful green chlorophyll. Tender and delicious 7-10 day microgreen sunflower shoots still produce as much fiber as fully matured fruits and vegetables but are much easier to chew and digest. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Herb Arugula - Slow Bolt - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Eruca Sativa Other Name(s): Roquette, salad rocket, garden rocket Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 9 grams Blackout Time: 1-2 days Germination Time: 1-2 days Estimated time to Harvest: 6-8 days Microgreen Color: green Microgreen Flavor: peppery flavor, slightly buttery and cabbage-like Microgreen Texture: crisp, fresh Nutrients: Vitamins A and C, calcium, iron, and phosphorus Growing Directions: Moisten soil, tamp, and spread the arugula seeds evenly over the growth surface. Cover for 1-2 days. Uncover and place under direct light, or place in an area with sufficient indirect light. Just be sure to rotate your microgreens crop to prevent your greens from bending toward the light and becoming leggy. Harvest when the look and the flavor is to your liking. So, begin sampling the greens when the first set of leaves form to determine when to cut! For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Arugula microgreens are wonderful for helping keep bones healthy and strong. The same amount of calcium is contained in arugula microgreens as is found in spinach. A benefit of the arugula microgreens is that it has a much lower amount of oxalates compared to spinach, which prevent full calcium absorption. Makes a fantastic garnish! Select a Different Use for This Seed: Garden Cabbage - Red Acre - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Brassica oleracea Other Name(s): Pak Choi, Bok Choy Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 2-4 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 6-14 days Microgreen Color: green leaves with violet to red highlights throughout Microgreen Flavor: strong broccoli/cabbage (brassica) flavor Microgreen Texture: soft and fresh Nutrients: Vitamins C, A, and E, beta-carotenes, potassium and iron Growing Directions: Red Acre Cabbage is easy to grow and grows quickly! It grows well in soil or on hydroponic mediums. If using soil, tamp and moisten soil before spreading your microgreen seeds across its surface. You may want to cover seeds with a thin layer of soil. This will keep the seeds moist for longer. Allowing the seeds to germinate on the surface is fine too! Keep dark with the black out dome for the first 3 days then flip the lid on day 4 and 5 to stress and strengthen the crop. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: A 2016 study by the American Chemical Society implies that red cabbage may help reduce \"bad\" cholesterol. Check out this vibrant kale microgreen with dark green leaves and variegated stems of pink, floral purple, and at times, bright red. It has a consistent flavor compared to other kale microgreens: nutty and robust'similiar to mustard, only less spicy! Select a Different Use for This Seed: Garden Kale - Red Russian - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Brassica oleracea Other Name(s): Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 1-2 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 8-12 days Microgreen Color: assorted red and pink stems with dark green leaves Microgreen Flavor: strong broccoli (brassica) flavor, nutty and rich Microgreen Texture: crunchy, fresh Nutrients: Vitamins A, C, and K, antioxidants, fiber, iron, and copper Growing Directions: Growing kale microgreens is quite easy. As long as you follow a few basic steps, you should have a plentiful harvest of microgreens in no time. Prepare your growth medium, whether it be soil or a hydroponic growth mat, by getting it sufficiently moist. Spread seeds evenly across the surface of the growth medium. The denser you sow the seeds, the thicker your crop will turn out. However, be wary of over-seeding, which can lead to to the seeds becoming overcrowded, leading to crop failure. After seeds are sown, cover for one to two days to allow seeds to germinate, and then uncover seeds and place under a grow light or in a place in your home that gets a lot of sunshine (rotate crop if next to a window to prevent \"bending\" in the microgreens). Continue to water when needed for up to a week and half. By then, you should have a bounty of little greens to incorporate into your meals. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Kale is an extremely nutrient dense food source. With microgreens you can receive all of the health benefits of kale and avoid the sometimes bitter taste that comes with full grown kale. Some of the health benefits of this amazing vegetable include: Full of antioxidants that reduce free radicals, which aids in cancer prevention Anti-inflammatory, which reduces swelling and pain in the body Fortifies immune system and improves brain health Seeds per Package: 1 oz - Approximately 8,000 seeds 4 oz - Approximately 32,000 seeds 1 lb - Approximately 128,000 seeds 5 lb - Approximately 640,000 seeds 25 lb - Approximately 3,200,000 seeds","descriptionHtml":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e8-12 days.\u003c/strong\u003e Check out this vibrant kale microgreen with dark green leaves and variegated stems of pink, floral purple, and at times, bright red. Red Garnet Amaranth is a high-protein microgreen with stunning red and magenta tones. This heirloom variety can be used in salads or many oriental dishes. Amaranth - Red Garnet - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Amaranthus tricolour Other Name(s): Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 2-4 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 8-12 days Microgreen Color: the most vibrant red and pink of any microgreen! Microgreen Flavor: mild, sweet flavor Microgreen Texture: crisp, fresh Nutrients: Vitamins K, E, and C, protein, calcium, iron, and beta-carotenes Growing Directions: Red Garnet Amaranth is a very small, delicate microgreen that prefers warmer growing conditions. Find a nice warm spot for germination and growing. It can also be sensitive to too much direct light. Red Garnet Amaranth does not grow tall, so expect very small greens that will need to be harvested close to the root line and rinsed well. These microgreens seeds do well grown hydroponically or in soil, but soil is a little more forgiving. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Red Garnet Amaranth contains a robust flavor, similar to mustard - but much less spicy. It can add depth to any dish that requires fresh greens--or in this case, reds! It's striking colors make it a great garnish or a lovely addition to any microgreen salad. Find a nice warm spot for germination and growing. It can also be sensitive to too much direct light. Red Garnet Amaranth does not grow tall, so expect very small greens that will need to be harvested close to the root line and rinsed well. These microgreens seeds do well grown hydroponically or in soil, but soil is a little more forgiving.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFor more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://trueleafmarket.reamaze.com/articles/growing-microgreens-in-soil\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSoil Growing Directions page\u003c/a\u003e or our\u003cspan\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca title=\"Microgreens Hydroponic Growing Directions\" href=\"https://trueleafmarket.reamaze.com/articles/how-to-grow-microgreens-hydroponically\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eHydroponic Growing Directions page\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFacts:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRed Garnet Amaranth contains a robust flavor, similar to mustard - but much less spicy. Dun Pea micro greens are one our all-time favorite microgreens! The pea shoots are sweet and delicious and fairly straight and leafy. They make a great garnish or addition to any salad. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Cover Crop Sprouting Pea - Dun - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Pisum sativum Other Name(s): Pea shoots Presoak: 4-6 hours in cold water (more details below) Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: Amount of seeds may vary. We recommend 5-8 oz Blackout Time: 3-5 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 8-14 days Pea Tendrils Amount: low Microgreen Color: green Microgreen Flavor: sweet, fresh pea taste Microgreen Texture: crunchy succulent Nutrients: Vitamins A, C, E, B1, B2, B3, B6, protein, fiber, omega-3 and micronutrients Growing Directions: Pea microgreens (also known as pea shoots) usually have very prominent root systems, which is why it is primarily grown in soil. The roots like to burrow and explore the soil while taking hold so the shoots can start \"shooting\" up. It is possible to get them to thrive with the right hydroponic medium. Soak seeds in cold water for 4-6 hours. Make sure you use plenty of water and a large bowl, as the peas soak up large amounts of water. You can plant directly, but we prefer to transfer to a colander. Rinse and drain 2-4 times per day in the colander for another day or two until the seedlings begin to peek out. Tamp the soil gently to flatten. Spread evenly (they should be quite thick) and tamp very gently to insure contact with the soil. Mist thoroughly twice a day. Keep covered with the blackout/humidity dome for 2-3 more days before exposing to light. Water once a day so the soil is damp, but not soggy. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Dun pea microgreens are an excellent source of these three protective agents: folate, antioxidants and carotene. Folate aids in the production and maintenance of cells, as well as protects against DNA damage Antioxidants fight against free radical damage, which lowers the risk of cancer Carotenes are helpful antioxidants that specifically protect the body from disease and strengthen the immune system Seeds per Package: 1 lb - Approximately 2,300 seeds 5 lb - Approximately 11,500 seeds 25 lb - Approximately 57,600 seeds","descriptionHtml":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e8-14 days\u003c/strong\u003e. Once they grow larger they get more leafy and lose their crunch. You can flip the lid a day before exposing to light to strengthen the crop. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Daikon Radish is a green crop with an intense radish flavor great in any microgreen salad or full sized salad. Daikon is one of the most popular radishes to sprout as well. Use instead of sliced radish anywhere you would normally use radish. Radish greens have a pleasant peppery bite, whether raw or cooked. A hearty salad made with these greens offers enough nourishment to reduce the need for snacking. This obviously cuts your caloric intake, which stabilizes your daily regimen. Beets are a more advanced microgreen, but well worth the effort because of its stunning color and bold flavor. It takes a bit more time to mature, but once grown, the bright stems and leaves look fantastic on any dish! Select a Different Use for This Seed: Garden Beet - Detroit Dark Red (Conventional) - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Beta vulgaris Other Name(s): Detroit Dark Red Presoak: 4-8 hours in cold water Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: up to 5 days Germination Time: 3-4 days Estimated time to Harvest: 11-21 days Microgreen Color: vibrant red stem with a nearly neon green top Microgreen Flavor: sweet and earthy Microgreen Texture: crunchy, juicy Nutrients: Vitamins A, B, C, E, and K, calcium, magnesium, potassium, iron, zinc, and protein Growing Directions: Grow beet microgreens seeds only in soil. Beet seeds are an abnormally shaped seed, which contributes to why its preferred medium is soil. Their root systems also require a bit more room to explore and grab hold.Prepare your soil in your tray by tamping it and making sure it is moist. After presoaking, sow your seeds and then cover with a thin layer of soil. This provides the ideal conditions for the seeds to germinate. After a while, the beets will start to poke through the the top layer\"which also serves to de-shell the seed. Keep covered with the blackout dome for up to five days. After that, place under a grow light or in sunlight until mature! Cut close to the soil line to feature the red stem. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page. Facts: Beets have so many healthy qualities! There are so many benefits to these tiny, yet powerful plants. A few of these health benefits include: Alleviates hypertension and cardiovascular disease Powerful detoxifying and antioxidant properties Improves immune functions Aids in preventing stroke, heart disease, risk of Type II diabetes, and epileptic seizures Stress relief Slows the aging process Seeds per Package: 4 oz - Approximately 5,000 seeds 1 lb - Approximately 20,000 seeds 5 lb - Approximately 100,000 seeds 25 lb - Approximately 500,000 seeds","descriptionHtml":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e11-21 days.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan\u003e \u003c/span\u003eBeets are a more advanced microgreen, but well worth the effort because of its stunning color and bold flavor. Detroit Dark Red (Conventional) - Microgreens Seeds \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003c!--attr--\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eLatin Name:\u003c/strong\u003e \u003cem\u003eBeta vulgaris\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eOther Name(s):\u003c/strong\u003e Detroit Dark Red\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003ePresoak:\u003c/strong\u003e 4-8 hours in cold water\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003ePreferred Growing Medium:\u003c/strong\u003e Hydroponic or Soil\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eSeeding Rate \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cem\u003eper 10\"x 20\" tray\u003c/em\u003e: 1 oz\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eBlackout Time:\u003c/strong\u003e up to 5 days\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eGermination Time:\u003c/strong\u003e 3-4 days\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eEstimated time to Harvest:\u003c/strong\u003e 11-21 days\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eMicrogreen Color:\u003c/strong\u003e vibrant red stem with a nearly neon green top\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eMicrogreen Flavor:\u003c/strong\u003e sweet and earthy\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eMicrogreen Texture:\u003c/strong\u003e crunchy, juicy\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eNutrients:\u003c/strong\u003e Vitamins A, B, C, E, and K, calcium, magnesium, potassium, iron, zinc, and protein\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c!--endattr--\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cbr\u003eGrowing Directions:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGrow beet microgreens seeds only in soil. Beet seeds are an abnormally shaped seed, which contributes to why its preferred medium is soil. Their root systems also require a bit more room to explore and grab hold.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003ePrepare your soil in your tray by tamping it and making sure it is moist. After presoaking, sow your seeds and then cover with a thin layer of soil. This provides the ideal conditions for the seeds to germinate. After a while, the beets will start to poke through the the top layer\"which also serves to de-shell the seed. Keep covered with the blackout dome for up to five days. After that, place under a grow light or in sunlight until mature! Green Pea microgreens are a staff favorite here at True Leaf! The tendrils add a unique texture while the stems have the same familiar crunch and sweet flavor of full grown peas. Green pea is a non-varietal species, and while Organic, can change in characteristics from harvest to harvest (including the amount of tendrils). The photo to the left is of a harvest of green peas with no tendrils. Often this variety has tendrils.~143 seeds/oz. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Sprouting Pea - Green (Organic) - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Pisum sativum Other Name(s): Pea shoots Presoak: 4-6 hours in cold water (more details below) Preferred Growing Medium: Soil (preferred) or Hydroponic (more difficult) Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: Amount of seeds may vary. We recommend 5-8 oz Blackout Time: 3-5 days Germination Time: 2-3 days Estimated time to Harvest: 8-14 days Pea Tendrils Amount: low to high (depending on the harvest) Microgreen Color: green Microgreen Flavor: sweet, fresh pea taste Microgreen Texture: crunchy, succulent Nutrients: Vitamins A, C, E, B1, B2, B3, B6, protein, fiber, omega-3 and micronutrients Growing Directions: Pea microgreens (also known as pea shoots) usually have very prominent root systems, which is why it is primarily grown in soil. The roots like to burrow and explore the soil while taking hold so the shoots can start \"shooting\" up. It is possible to get them to thrive with the right hydroponic medium. Soak seeds in cold water for 4-6 hours. Make sure you use plenty of water and a large bowl, as the peas soak up large amounts of water. You can plant directly, but we prefer to transfer to a colander. Rinse and drain 2-4 times per day in the colander for another day or two until the seedlings begin to peek out. Tamp the soil gently to flatten. Spread evenly (they should be quite thick) and tamp very gently to insure contact with the soil. Mist thoroughly twice a day. Keep covered with the blackout/humidity dome for 2-3 more days before exposing to light. Water once a day so the soil is damp, but not soggy. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page or our Hydroponic Growing Directions page Facts: Pea microgreens can aid in diabetes, cancer prevention and overall heart health. They are high in antioxidants and phytonutrients, which are necessary in supporting the body's inflammation system. days. This slow-bolting strain is grown primarily for its broad, deep green, celery-like, pungent foliage. As a microgreen, these seeds take time but are well worth it, not only for the strong cilantro flavor but for the sweet aroma the greens emit. Select a Different Use for This Seed: Herb Cilantro - Slow Bolt - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Coriandrum sativum Other Name(s): Coriander, dhania Presoak: 4-8 hours in cold water Preferred Growing Medium: Soil (difficult to grow hydroponically) Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 6-7 days Germination Time: 7-10 days Estimated time to Harvest: 21-28 days Microgreen Color: green Microgreen Flavor: full cilantro flavor Microgreen Texture: crisp, fresh Nutrients: Vitamins A, C, E, K, calcium, iron, potassium, dietary fiber and magnesium Growing Directions: Cilantro (also called coriander) is very difficult to grow hydroponically. We recommend growing micro cilantro in soil. Germination of cilantro microgreens is erratic with some emerging at about a week, and some seeds taking longer, so be patient with them. The seed itself is actually the dried ripe fruit of the plant, called a shizocarp. A schizocarp is a dry fruit that splits into single-seeded parts when ripe. Splitting or cracking can help with germination by releasing the seed. Here's how: Place seed in a zip-lock bag and roll over it with a rolling pin to release the individual seeds, rinse in a fine mesh strainer and soak overnight for even germination. Sow quite thickly on a bed of lightly compacted soil. Cover with a thin layer of soil or vermiculite (1/4 inch) and tamp very lightly. Cover in a humidity dome and mist as needed to keep the top layer medium damp. Cilantro micro greens grow slowly and prefer cooler temperatures (under 70 degrees), especially during germination. Experiment with placing your germinating trays in much cooler areas. For more detailed instructions on growing, as well as some troubleshooting and tips, please visit our Soil Growing Directions page Facts: Some of the amazing health benefits of cilantro are: Eliminates heavy metals from the body Powerful antioxidant that reduces free radicals, which aids in cancer prevention Reduces anxiety and improves sleep Seeds per Package: 1 oz - Approximately 2,000 seeds 4 oz - Approximately 8,000 seeds 1 lb - Approximately 32,000 seeds 5 lb - Approximately 160,000 seeds 25 lb - Approximately 800,000 seeds","descriptionHtml":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e21-28 days.\u003c/strong\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThis slow-bolting strain is grown primarily for its broad, deep green, celery-like, pungent foliage. As a microgreen, these seeds take time but are well worth it, not only for the strong cilantro flavor but for the sweet aroma the greens emit.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eSelect a Different Use for This Seed:\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"profile-links\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"/products/cilantro-slow-bolt-herb-seeds?variant=38818632584\"\u003e \u003cimg src=\"https://cdn.shopify.com/s/files/1/2016/2681/files/tlm-herbs.png?11208874335812730243\"\u003e\u003cu\u003eHerb\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!--split--\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCilantro - Slow Bolt - Microgreens Seeds \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003c!--attr--\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eLatin Name:\u003c/strong\u003e \u003cem\u003eCoriandrum sativum\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eOther Name(s):\u003c/strong\u003e Coriander, dhania\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003ePresoak:\u003c/strong\u003e 4-8 hours in cold water\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003ePreferred Growing Medium:\u003c/strong\u003e Soil (difficult to grow hydroponically)\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eSeeding Rate \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cem\u003eper 10\"x 20\" tray\u003c/em\u003e: 1 oz\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eBlackout Time:\u003c/strong\u003e 6-7 days\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eGermination Time:\u003c/strong\u003e 7-10 days\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eEstimated time to Harvest:\u003c/strong\u003e 21-28 days\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eMicrogreen Color:\u003c/strong\u003e green\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eMicrogreen Flavor:\u003c/strong\u003e full cilantro flavor\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eMicrogreen Texture:\u003c/strong\u003e crisp, fresh\u003c/li\u003e\n \u003cli\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eNutrients:\u003c/strong\u003e Vitamins A, C, E, K, calcium, iron, potassium, dietary fiber and magnesium\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c!--endattr--\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cbr\u003eGrowing Directions:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCilantro (also called coriander) is very difficult to grow hydroponically. We recommend growing micro cilantro in soil. Germination of cilantro microgreens is erratic with some emerging at about a week, and some seeds taking longer, so be patient with them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe seed itself is actually the dried ripe fruit of the plant, called a shizocarp. A schizocarp is a dry fruit that splits into single-seeded parts when ripe. \u003cem\u003eSplitting or cracking can help with germination by releasing the seed.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere's how: Place seed in a zip-lock bag and roll over it with a rolling pin to release the individual seeds, rinse in a fine mesh strainer and soak overnight for even germination.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSow quite thickly on a bed of lightly compacted soil. Cover with a thin layer of soil or vermiculite (1/4 inch) and tamp very lightly. Cover in a humidity dome and mist as needed to keep the top layer medium damp. Cilantro micro greens grow slowly and prefer cooler temperatures (under 70 degrees), especially during germination. Experiment with placing your germinating trays in much cooler areas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ciframe src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/s7d_-b61kGw\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; Select a Different Use for This Seed: Herb Basil - Genovese - Microgreens Seeds Latin Name: Ocimum basilcum Other Name(s): Presoak: No Soak Preferred Growing Medium: Hydroponic or Soil Seeding Rate per 10\"x 20\" tray: 1 oz Blackout Time: 4-7 days Germination Time: 5-7 days Estimated time to Harvest: 12-16 days Microgreen Color: green Microgreen Flavor: intense basil Microgreen Texture: soft Nutrients: Vitamins E, A, K, B6, and C, protein, calcium, iron, zinc, magnesium, copper, phosphorous, and potassium Growing Directions: Genovese Basil is a mucilaginous seed, meaning that it develops a jelly-like coating when it gets wet. Mist more frequently to keep the coating moist. Grows very well hydroponically and does better in well-lit conditions, but it is a slower grower. You may experiment with harvest times past 10 days. Genovese basil is a beautiful green color with an interesting shape that makes for a colorful garnish. Micro basil does not grow tall, so you will need to harvest close to the root line and rinse well. Micro basil seeds are among the more expensive seeds, but are worth it for their intense basil flavor. ***Note: Although we have indicated the specific medium that this particular seed prefers, you can still experiment with either Hydroponic or Soil mediums. The microgreen is substantial and very crunchy. Due to its fast growth it can be harvested as early as 6 days, assuming you have exposed it to light on day 3. These radish microgreens are at their peak of crunchiness at about day 5 or 6. Once they grow larger they get more leafy and lose their crunch. You can flip the lid a day before exposing to light to strengthen the crop.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e***Note: Although we have indicated the specific medium that this particular seed prefers, you can still experiment with either Hydroponic or Soil mediums.
